# What is Quarto?

---


## Introduction


::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
::: fragment
### Quarto is an

-   Open-source
-   Scientific and technical publishing system (build on Pandoc Markdown)
-   Supports multiple programming languages (Python, R Julia, Observable)
-   Can run code and show results 
-   Create documents in many formats (HTML, PDF, Word, Revealjs, etc.)
-   Can be used e.g. via `VSCode` or `RStudio`
-   Visit [quarto.org](https://quarto.org) to get a first impression

:::
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
::: {.fragment}
### Usecases

1.  Manuscripts/Reports
2.  **Websites**
3.  Dashboards
4. Books
5. Presentations
:::
:::
:::

## Getting started: Setup and Installation

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
::: fragment
### Tools to work with Quarto

You can use one of the following editors:

-   **VS Code**
-   RStudio
-   Jupyter
-   Neovim
-   Text editor

:::
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
::: {.fragment}
### Creating a Quarto setup in VSCode and RStudio

::: {.panel-tabset}

### VS Code 
1. Download and install [the newest version of VS Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/download) and [Python](https://www.python.org/downloads/) 
2. Open VS Code
3. Open a terminal and activate your existing environment
```{.python code-line-numbers="1-2"}
conda activate TessaPyEnv
# if the environment doesn't exist yet, create it first
```
4. Install Quarto within your environment
```{.python code-line-numbers="1-4"}
conda install -c conda-forge quarto
# verify the installation (if it prints a version number, it's ready to use)
quarto --version 
```

### RStudio
1.  Download and install [the newest version of RStudio](https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/)
2.  Open RStudio
3.  Create a new `.qmd` file: "File" > "New file" > "Quarto Document"

:::
:::
:::
:::

## Setup a HTML Website project folder: Structure in VS Code 

Quarto websites are built from multiple documents (e.g., `.ipynb`, `.qmd`) that share navigational elements, rendering options, and visual style.

- `_quarto.yml`: website configuration (navigation, theme, format)
- `index.qmd`: Homepage (requiered)
- `about.qmd`: top-level page (e.g. project information)
- `contact.qmd`: top-level page (e.g. contact persons)
- additional files for example:
  - folder `docs`
    - `index.qmd` (nested landing page within the folder)
    - `ecological-momentary-assessment.qmd` (alternatively `.ipynb`)
    - `passive-sensing.qmd`
  - folder `images`
    - including files like `.png`


---

## YAML header

`_quarto.yml`

```{.python code-line-numbers="1-60"}
project:
  type: website
  output-dir: _site
  render:
    - "quarto/*.qmd"
    - "quarto/*.ipynb"
    - "code/notebooks/*.ipynb"
    - "!code/notebooks/er_aggregation.ipynb"


website:
  title: "FOR5187 | PREACT"
  #logo: "images/tiki.png"  # Make sure this path is correct
  navbar:
    left: []  # explicitly empty
    pinned: true

  sidebar:
    style: "docked"
    collapse-level: 1
    contents:
      - href: quarto/index.qmd
        text: Home
      - href: quarto/quick_overview.ipynb
        text: Study Overview
      - href: quarto/documentation.ipynb
        text: Feature Documentation
      - section: Preprocessing
        contents:
        - href: quarto/EMA preprocessing.ipynb
          text: EMA preprocessing
        - href: quarto/Passive preprocessing.ipynb
          text: Passive preprocessing
        - href: quarto/ECG preprocessing.ipynb
          text: ECG preprocessing


  format:
    html:
      theme:
      - cosmo
      - brand
      css: quarto/styles.css
      toc: true
```

## How to render Quarto files


:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="40%"}
### 1. Preview

- The document will be rendered and a web browser with a "live preview" opened (localhost)
- Position this browser so that you can see it as you edit and save the document
- Every time you save, the preview will be updated

**Terminal:**
```{.python code-line-numbers="1-60"}
quarto preview
```

![](images/rendering.png){height=300px}

:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
### 2. Render

- Render a document (or group of documents) without previewing them

**Terminal:**
```{.python code-line-numbers="1-60"}
quarto render
```

:::

::::

## Key Considerations for Deciding Whether to Use Quarto & GitHub Pages for your Data Documentation

1. **Time and staff capacity:** Enough time and personel capacities to set it up? 

    - Does the setup effort justify the benefit?
    (PDFs may be quicker for simple and not so extensive documentation)
2. **Public accessibility**
  
    - Websites published via GitHub Pages are publicly accessible by default (cost-free)
    - To publish a site privately (e.g., for only FOR intern use), you must use [GitHub Enterprise Cloud](https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/overview/setting-up-a-trial-of-github-enterprise-cloud) (not cost-free)
    - Alternatives: see [here](https://quarto.org/docs/publishing/)
